topic.title: Help! Cannot sign and publish site: "VerifyError: Content too large"
topic.body: While attempting to verify and publish my site to zeronet, I recieved the following error: VerifyError: Content too large 99999999B > 10485760B, aborting task... in main.py line 198 > ContentManager.py line 736 > ContentManager.py line 841 I have tried, rather hopelessly, to reduce the overall size of the site I am attempting to upload, and regardless of how small I reduce the site, I am still receiving the same error preventing me from publishing my site. 10485760B is only about 10MB, which I am sure there are other sites on ZeroNet much larger than this. Any suggestions or insight into what is going on and preventing me from signing my site, would be greatly appreciated.

1558748943_1it9RV9vuxwM3fEdT6B9k5sGjn91k.body: I have already filled an issue in the github project page yesterday, and so far have not received any help or hints on how to resolve this problem. Also, enabling debugging on ZeroNet did not provide any useful information on what could be causing the issue.

> [znuser2](#comment_1_1Gc3uLxhgPABiU5HAE1vQNAo5VWoHtNHho): i've had the same problem and was able to solve it after reducing my content to a little bit less than 10 MB and modyfing the main index.html before publishing...

Thanks for the response. I am currently working on shrinking down the size of the site, and seeing if that works. It is hard for me to believe this 10MB limitation of site size is intentional considering the size of images now these days is about 1MB. Regardless, I just wonder what could be causing this limitation? If it was intentional, what was the reasoning for this? If not, then what factors could be causing this limitation?

> [znuser2](#comment_2_1Gc3uLxhgPABiU5HAE1vQNAo5VWoHtNHho): Downloading more than 10 MB requires user interaction and that's a good thing. It protects the visitor from accidentally downloading a huge site. Someone could create a 1TB zite and flood your hard drive with garbage.

True, but every website I have visited on ZeroNet so far is well above 10MBs in size. 

Now, there might be a limitation on the size allowed per site signing. This might be a possibility, and a variable that could be playing a part in this limitation is system processing power and ram amount. Since signing certificates is processor intensive. This is what I am beginning to think might be the situation. But, it still does not make much sense because, the overall load on my system is actually relatively low.

> [znuser2](#comment_1_1Gc3uLxhgPABiU5HAE1vQNAo5VWoHtNHho): i've had the same problem and was able to solve it after reducing my content to a little bit less than 10 MB and modyfing the main index.html before publishing...

Well, what do you know? I scrapped my original site and started completely over, with a completely different webpage, bare as bones, that was under 10MB and, viola! It uploaded without a hitch. Now, I am going to see if I can expand the size of the site now it is signed.
And, I went full retard... nobody should go full retard... Every site is "contained" and encrypted in a "container", given an initial and intentional 10MB limit".
